abstract.text: The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in significant changes in health care systems worldwide, 2 with low-and middle-income countries (LMIC) sustaining important repercussions.

body_text.text: In a matter of weeks, the COVID-19 crisis led to the cancelation and indefinite 23 postponements of countless surgical clinics and elective surgeries in favor of redirecting 24 resources towards the pandemic preparedness and response. As the pandemic paralyzes some 25 of the world's most robust health systems, how will surgical ecosystems in LMICs cope with 26 the crisis, in which health systems are comparatively weaker? as canceling all non-essential surgical elective procedures and outpatient clinics, urgent and 48 emergent surgical diseases will continue to occur and contribute to avoidable morbidity and 49 mortality. FIGREF0.text: quality and affordable surgical healthcare--including the entire surgical 29 ecosystem, obstetrics, gynecology, and anesthesia--is a crucial component of population 30 health. 1 In low-and middle-income countries (LMICs), where a focus on infectious diseases 31 and maternal and child health has prevailed, access to quality surgical care is especially 32 deficient. 2 The world's poorest third receive only 6% of the global surgical volume, despite 33 incurring a more considerable burden of surgical diseases. 3,4 To address the unmet need for 34 surgical healthcare in LMICs, it is estimated that an additional 2.2 million surgeons, 35 obstetricians, and anesthesiologists are needed, in addition to investments in the surgical 36 equipment and infrastructure. 2 The decades-long omission of comprehensive health systems 37 strengthening efforts in LMICs has left health systems inadequately resourced and sub-38 optimally organized and governed especially in regard to surgical healthcare services. Now, 39 the novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic could overwhelm the frail health 40 systems found in several LMICs, inevitably wiping out the already limited and scanty 41 surgical healthcare services in many countries around the world. This situation calls for the 42 need to reflect on the consequences of the pandemic on emergency and essential surgical care, 43 especially in LMICs, and to elaborate on solutions to prevent and minimize them.

FIGREF2.text: 52 difficult and complicated childbirth, acute abdomen, falls, burns, strokes, aortic dissections, 53 myocardial infarctions, and soft tissue infections, amongst many other conditions. It is 54 estimated that 15% of pregnancies require surgical care, including the management of 55 postpartum hemorrhage, obstructed labor, and cesarean sections. 6 Children continue to be 56 born with congenital defects that require lifesaving surgical management, including 57 congenital heart defects, gastroschisis, neural tube defects, and other conditions. Failure to 58 manage these surgical conditions would result in decreased quality of life, increased 59 morbidity, and many lives lost. Conversely, by still managing these patients during the 60 current pandemic, infection risks may be heightened amongst healthcare professionals due to 61 higher viral load as a result of prolonged exposure and limited personal protective equipment 62 (PPE). Moreover, the positive pressure maintained in the few well-equipped operating rooms 63 in LMICs, and the experimental evidence suggesting potential airborne and, especially, 64 surface stability of SARS-CoV-2 is of concern--creating a potential wind tunnel of viral particles. 7 66 67 COVID-19 has produced profound and unprecedented shifts within the surgical 68 workforce at a global level. In most epicenters worldwide, the explosive number of COVID-69 19 patients has pulled surgical staff out of operating rooms into the emergency department 70 and intensive care units (ICUs). Although health workers fight to contain COVID-19 and 71 treat the most vulnerable and critical patients, they are at heightened risk of becoming 72 infected themselves--ultimately turning into disease vectors themselves. As PPE constraints grow, the number of infections of health care workers grows accordingly. In Spain and Italy, 74 10-15% of all SARS-CoV-2 infections were frontline health care workers taking care of 75 patients. 8,9 In Wuhan, the first days and weeks of the outbreak before the true gravity was 76 known, patients were operated on non-stop until it became clear that surgical providers were 77 becoming infected one by one. 10 In Boston, a city that is comparatively well-resourced in 78 terms of health infrastructure and systems, more than 150 health care workers tested positive 79 for COVID-19 early in the US outbreak, whereas cities across the US have been witnessing 80 the first deaths of healthcare workers. 11,12 It is to be expected that these developments have 81 even more grave consequences in LMICs, where the luxury does not exist to pull the limited 82 surgical workforce out of the operating rooms whilst maintaining emergency and essential 83surgical care delivery, and where screening, testing, and PPE is even less accessible.

FIGREF3.text: COVID-19 on surgical ecosystems in LMICs 86 A loss of sparse health care workers in LMICs could have devastating effects on 87 health care delivery. While most LMICs have yet to climb the curve as North America and 88 Europe, others are racing steeply upwards. 13 For instance, as of May 9th, 2020, Iran has 89 surpassed 106,000 reported cases while Turkey and Brazil keep ascending with over 137,000 90 and 148,000 confirmed cases, respectively, with potentially much higher numbers given under the supervision of surgeons and anesthesiologists, who have undergone to safely don and take off COVID-19-appropriate PPE ought to be 150 taught to all health care workers involved with operative care to minimize infection and 151 spread. Rapid sequence endotracheal intubation, only provided that there are adequate 152 material resources and physical protection for the clinician, is recommended for COVID-19 153 patients. 21 Ensuring a reliable fine-particle filter between the ventilator and the patient, as 154 well as care in avoiding tubing disconnections, are necessary precautions. Reorganization of 155 surgical teams, such as dedicating specific individuals to treat surgical patients with COVID-156 19, should be established with the objective of decreasing staff rotation, contamination of 157 personnel, and optimizing the distribution of limited surgical staff. 158 Similarly, recognizing the vital role of critical care nurses in the delivery of care for 159 COVID-19 patients in the ICU and on ventilation, surgical providers ought to engage with 160 and learn the management of critical care patients to serve in the same role when and where 161 needed. Surgical on-call teams can be formed to support the emergency department and ICU 162 in, for example, placing central venous lines and intubating patients.

FIGREF4.text: Secure adequate maintenance of PPE stocks. 164 In order to take care of patients, providers first have to take care of themselves. PPE is 165 paramount to protect health care workers from contracting the virus and becoming disease 166 carriers. Make-shift recommendations have included the use of cloth masks and bandanas, 167 although the moisture retention, reusability, and filtration is inferior to that of surgical and 168 N95 masks. 22 While counterintuitive, healthcare workers ought to consider refraining from caring 170 for patients in the absence of PPE, as observed during the plague, Spanish Flu, and Ebola 171 outbreaks when PPE shortages were widespread. 23 Heroism is critically dangerous given the172 need to self-isolate--and thus falling out of the workforce--or spreading the virus, lining for LMICs? Decades of resource constraints and the fight against 177 endemic infectious diseases and outbreaks have led to the development of robust public 178 health surveillance systems and innovation in rapidly deploying population-level 179 interventions to mitigate spread. 24 As a result, LMICs have already empowered their 180 communities to work within and beyond structures of the local health system to spread 181 community awareness, especially in times of crisis. 25 The Ebola outbreaks in West and 182 Central Africa, including the prominent 2014-2015 outbreak, have brought important lessons 183 on adequately maintaining hygiene and ensuring swift contact tracing--crucial, especially so 184 with a condition as fatal as Ebola. 26 In Southeast Asia, the SARS and MERS epidemics 185 equipped countries with emergency preparedness plans to swiftly identify asymptomatic 186 carriers at the borders, whilst normalizing a culture of public mask-wearing. 27,28 This latter 187 practice indirectly maintained large volumes of surgical and N95 masks in stock. Previous 188 crisis experiences primed authorities and populations in LMICs for better cohesion towards 189 public health rules, which contrasts with the tempered approach in several North American 190 epicenters. Furthermore, as LMIC surgeons face a chronic shortage in personnel and 191 resources, prioritizing and task-shifting are everyday practices, even though the weight of the 192 pandemic will require further adaptation for this scarce workforce. The COVID-19 pandemic 193 can highlight the value of the surgical system as a source of immediate treatment capacity. As 194 such, building up surgical capacity in the LMIC serves to improve surgical access time of crisis, high-income countries are encouraged to integrate innovative 198 practices in order to bring in low-cost, low-resource, and accessible solutions rapidly to scale. 199 Low-resource settings have been breeding grounds for innovative ideas, often having to rely 200 on ingenious methods to provide the care that is needed--for example, finding means to 201 sterilize and re-use equipment and consumables. Now, with the need to find solutions to an 202 impending shortage of ventilators, lessons may be learned from our colleagues in LMICs to 203 develop low-cost, rapid, and temporary solutions to develop make-shift ventilators and 204 maximize treatment capacity. A prime example has been the recent development of a 205 multidisciplinary collaborative involving the surgical innovation team and the department of 206 surgery at Boston Children's Hospital to produce quality N95-like masks costing only 3 US 207 dollars per unit, in response to the emergent lack in PPE. 29 Besides material needs, HICs can 208 also inspire themselves from LMICs' task-sharing and task-shifting practices both within and 209 beyond the surgical ecosystem. 30 This practice could imply a temporary change in the skill 210 set of non-physician health care professionals in carrying out simple but necessary tasks and 211 assignments in response to the shortage of physician staff in hospitals.

As several North 216 American surgical societies have already shared COVID-19 resources on their webpages, 217 communication, and collaborations with their African, South Asian, and Latin American 218 counterparts should be encouraged. Exchanges can pertain from their learnings on providing 219 patients outside their area of expertise to dealing with prioritizing surgeries. These messages 220 are increasing in urgency as cases in Africa, South Asia, and Latin America are climbing fast, 221 with countries such as India and South Africa recently entering national lockdowns.
